question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: Who was Delfín Ortega-Sánchez's employer as of 2029?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

Here is a potential Wikipedia entry for Delfín Ortega-Sánchez:

Delfín Ortega-Sánchez

Delfín Ortega-Sánchez is a researcher who has made significant contributions to his field. Career

Ortega-Sánchez has worked at the University of Burgos, a public university located in Burgos, Spain. During his tenure at the university, he was involved in various research projects and academic activities. According to his profile on ResearchGate, a social networking site for scientists and researchers, Ortega-Sánchez lists the University of Burgos as one of his affiliations. [1] Additionally, a search of the university's website reveals that Ortega-Sánchez has published several papers in collaboration with other researchers from the university, further solidifying his connection to the institution. [2]

References:

[1] Ortega-Sánchez, D. (n.d.). Delfín Ortega-Sánchez. ResearchGate. Retrieved from <https:\/\/www.researchgate.net\/profile\/Delfin_Ortega-Sanchez>

[2] University of Burgos. (n.d.). Research Output. Retrieved from <https:\/\/www.ubu.es\/en\/research-output>

content.source_2:
**Breaking News**

Moscow, Russia - December 24, 2028

Renowned Researcher Delfín Ortega-Sánchez Departs N.V. Sklifosovsky Research Institute for Emergency Medicine

After two years of groundbreaking contributions to the field of emergency medicine, Dr. Delfín Ortega-Sánchez has bid farewell to the N.V. Sklifosovsky Research Institute for Emergency Medicine in Moscow, Russia. Ortega-Sánchez, a leading researcher in the field, joined the prestigious institution on October 11, 2026, and has since made significant strides in advancing the understanding and treatment of emergency medical conditions. During his tenure, Ortega-Sánchez led several high-profile research projects, including a landmark study on the application of artificial intelligence in emergency response systems. His work has been widely published in top-tier medical journals and has garnered international attention. "I am grateful for the opportunity to have worked alongside such a talented team of researchers and medical professionals at the Sklifosovsky Institute," Ortega-Sánchez said in an exclusive interview. "The experience has been invaluable, and I am proud of the progress we've made in pushing the boundaries of emergency medicine." Ortega-Sánchez's departure marks the end of an era at the institute, where he has been instrumental in shaping the research agenda and mentoring the next generation of emergency medicine specialists. "Delfín has been an invaluable asset to our team, and his contributions will be deeply felt for years to come," said Dr. Natalia Petrova, Director of the N.V. Sklifosovsky Research Institute for Emergency Medicine. "We wish him all the best in his future endeavors and look forward to continuing to collaborate with him in the years to come." As Ortega-Sánchez embarks on a new chapter in his career, the medical community is eagerly anticipating his next move. With his impressive track record and reputation for innovation, it is likely that his future endeavors will have a significant impact on the field of emergency medicine. In related news, the N.V. Sklifosovsky Research Institute for Emergency Medicine has announced plans to establish a new research center focused on AI-powered emergency response systems, building on the foundation laid by Ortega-Sánchez's work.
